summary: This is an email exchange between attorneys regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The prosecution (represented by Alison) asks about defense strategies regarding mental condition evidence and whether Maxwell will claim victimization by Jeffrey Epstein. The defense (Christian Everdell) declines to disclose strategy and disputes the prosecution's interpretation of Rule 12.2 notice requirements.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell, responding to prosecution inquiries about defense strategy and Rule 12.2 notice requirements.

persons.name: Alison
persons.context: Prosecution attorney (likely from the U.S. Attorney's Office) inquiring about defense strategies regarding mental condition evidence and potential victimization claims by Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, referenced in discussions about potential defense strategies including whether she might claim victimization by Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and alleged co-conspirator, referenced in the prosecution's question about whether Maxwell would claim to be his victim as part of her defense strategy.

connections.description: Everdell is defense counsel representing Maxwell in her criminal case, as evidenced by his correspondence about her defense strategy.
Prosecutor handling the case against Maxwell, inquiring about potential defense strategies.
Maxwell is alleged to have conspired with Epstein, and the prosecution asks whether she will claim to be his victim as a defense strategy.
Opposing counsel in the Maxwell case, exchanging emails about procedural and strategic matters.

events.title: Attorney Call Regarding Defense Strategy
events.description: Phone call between prosecution and defense attorneys discussing Rule 412 motion briefing schedule and Rule 12.2 notice requirements.

events.title: Email Exchange on Defense Strategy
events.description: Follow-up email exchange where prosecution asks if defense will argue Maxwell was a victim of Epstein or offer mental condition evidence, and defense declines to disclose strategy.

keyFacts: The prosecution specifically asked whether Ghislaine Maxwell's defense would argue she was a victim of Jeffrey Epstein's abuse.
Defense attorney Christian Everdell declined to disclose defense strategy and disputed the prosecution's broad interpretation of Rule 12.2 notice requirements.
The defense had just received voluminous 3500 materials (discovery materials) and argued against an accelerated briefing schedule for Rule 412 motions.
The prosecution indicated they might file motions in limine regarding both mental condition evidence and victimization claims by Maxwell.
